channel.title: Ec2
channel.description:
http://aws.amazon.com/ec2/
has anyone used this service before? I am thinking of this as scalability is an issue for me.

item.title: Ec2
item.dc:creator: @Cheese_Police c|p
item.description:
@Cheese_Police wrote:

EC2 is a bit spendy, but S3 is pretty affordable if you need a lot of storage ‘in the cloud’.

Read full topic

item.title: Ec2
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I’ve tried it (the free instance), I actually used it for a few hours to block a large DDos attack on the forums once (used it as a reverse-proxy), and it still cost me $20 to cover the bandwidth.

But hey, try the free version out for a year and see how you like it:
http://aws.amazon.com/free/
Personally I think it’s too expensive to be worth it for the average joe.

Read full topic

item.title: Ec2
item.dc:creator: @teh_spede Teh Spede
item.description:
@teh_spede wrote:

Looked into this a couple of days ago when vortex showed it to me. I was going to try it out but it didn’t like my Visa Electron.

Read full topic

item.title: Ec2
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

[quote=“Miss Silabsoft, post:2, topic:432878”]Hi-Memory On-Demand Instances
Extra Large $0.50 per hour $0.62 per hour
Double Extra Large $1.00 per hour $1.24 per hour
Quadruple Extra Large $2.00 per hour $2.48 per hour

hard to take descriptions like that seriously, also seems really expensive[/quote]

High-Memory Quadruple Extra Large Instance

68.4 GB of memory
26 EC2 Compute Units (8 virtual cores with 3.25 EC2 Compute Units each)
1690 GB of instance storage
64-bit platform
I/O Performance: High
API name: m2.4xlarge

To make it easy for developers to compare CPU capacity between different instance types, we defined an Amazon EC2 Compute Unit. One EC2 Compute Unit provides the equivalent CPU capacity of a 1.0-1.2 GHz 2007 Opteron or 2007 Xeon processor.

sure it’s expensive but holy shitballs

Read full topic
